It is characterized by its woody stems and distinctive, four-armed, spiny fruits that develop from its small, green flowers. The plant is native to arid and semi-arid regions of southern Africa, where it thrives in sandy or gravelly soils. Its unique morphology makes it well adapted to harsh environmental conditions, and it often plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat. Wigginsia tetracantha is primarily valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological contributions in its native range.
